author: By Elian Peltier
title: E. U. Proposes New Travel Restrictions on Unvaccinated U.S. Visitors
description: The door that opened in June may close for some again as E.U. officials see American coronavirus cases surge.
content: BRUSSELS — Back in June, the European Union urged its member countries to reopen their borders to travelers from the United States, hoping to give a boost to the continent’s ailing tourism sector in the crucial summer season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China Tightens Limits for Young Online Gamers and Bans School Night Play
description: The restrictions reflect the government’s intensifying push for companies to jettison what it says are unhealthy cultural influences.
content: China’s strict limits on how long minors can play online video games just got stricter. Chinese children and teenagers are barred from online gaming on school days, and limited to one hour a day on weekend and holiday evenings, under government rules issued Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: The U.S. reaches a daily average of 100,000 Covid hospitalizations for the first time since the winter peak.
description: Hospitalizations nationwide have increased by nearly 500 percent in the past two months, particularly across Southern states, where I.C.U. beds are filling up.
content: The daily average for hospitalized Covid-19 patients in the United States is now more than 100,000 over the last week. That average is higher than in any previous surge except last winter’s, before most Americans were eligible to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: California’s Plan to Make New Buildings Greener Will Also Raise Costs
description: A recent building code change for new construction could reduce emissions by requiring use of solar panels and batteries, raising prices in an already expensive state.
content: California has led the nation in fighting climate change by encouraging the use of renewable energy and electric cars. Now the state is taking on an even harder challenge — reducing emissions from homes, businesses and other buildings that have to be heated, cooled and powered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Lighter Side of Octopus
description: The chef Justin Smillie shaves the octopus into long strips for his summer dish at Il Buco Al Mare.
content: Justin Smillie, the executive chef for the Il Buco restaurants in Manhattan and in Amagansett, N.Y., wanted to devise a lighter take on octopus. “I was looking for something other than the big steaky chunks you always see,” he said. So instead of cutting meaty cross-sections of the tentacles, he shaved them into ribbons the long way, quickly seared the strips on a plancha and tossed them with tiny tomatoes, herbs, a bit of Fresno chile and olive oil for his delectable, crispy octopus dish ($26, among the small plates at Il Buco Al Mare). He starts with cooked octopus and uses a meat slicer; for home cooks, a sharp knife works. He recommends marinating the strips before cooking, and also suggests threading them on skewers or tossing them with pasta or into rice dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. War in Afghanistan Ends as Final Evacuation Flights Depart
description: The last U.S. military plane left Kabul Monday night, ending a presence that spanned two decades but failed to defeat the Taliban and left behind tens of thousands of Afghans.
content: The last United States forces left Afghanistan late Monday, ending a 20-year occupation that began shortly after Al Qaeda’s attacks on 9/11, cost over $2 trillion, took more than 170,000 lives and ultimately failed to defeat the Taliban, the Islamist militants who allowed Al Qaeda to operate there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Faces Rare Union Challenge as Buffalo Workers Seek Vote
description: The organizing campaign, if successful, could upend the company’s labor model. Employees say chronic understaffing has long caused frustration.
content: For years, Starbucks workers have complained about the company’s labor practices, saying that chronic understaffing has led to a chaotic work environment, erratic hours and difficulty taking sick days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Kenny Malone, Premier Drummer for Top Nashville Names, Dies at 83
description: He propelled hits by stars in country, folk and pop, including Dolly Parton, Crystal Gayle, Ray Charles, Waylon Jennings, Kenny Rogers and Bela Fleck.
content: NASHVILLE — Kenny Malone, a prolific Nashville session drummer whose skittering snare rhythms haunted Dolly Parton’s No. 1 country hit “Jolene” in 1973 and whose cocktail-jazz groove anchored Crystal Gayle’s crossover smash “Don’t It Make My Brown Eyes Blue” in 1977, died at a hospital here on Thursday. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Preserving the Season at Its Peak
description: Try these three methods to capture the essence of summer fruit in jams and jellies.
content: There’s almost no way around the fact that making preserves is a process. But for me that’s what is so enjoyable about it. I am, to a fault, a process person. I revel in precision and attention to detail — these are my superpowers. They’re why I’m drawn to making preserves. In returning to the tradition each year, I have found that I’m always seeking the same thing: to capture memories of farm visits, perfect produce and the season’s warmth in small glass jars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Opens New Federal Office for Climate Change, Health and Equity
description: The office will be the first government effort to focus specifically on the public health dangers of global warming.
content: WASHINGTON — Amid deadly heat waves and new evidence showing that wildfire smoke may contribute to premature births, the Biden administration is creating a new federal office to address the health consequences of climate change and their disproportionate effects on poor communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Dan Bilefsky
title: U.S. shoots down rockets aimed at Kabul’s airport.
description: The attacks came with just two days remaining before President Biden’s deadline to complete the withdrawal, capping 20 years of war in Afghanistan.
content: The U.S. military shot down rockets aimed at the Kabul airport on Monday morning as violence near the field threatened efforts by the United States to meet Tuesday’s deadline to withdraw from Afghanistan and end America’s longest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The U.S. Education Department is investigating five states over their mask mandate bans.
description: Federal officials said the prohibitions may run afoul of civil rights laws protecting students with disabilities.
content: WASHINGTON — The Education Department has initiated investigations into five states whose prohibitions on universal mask mandates in schools may run afoul of civil rights laws protecting students with disabilities, federal officials announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Virginia School Board to Pay $1.3 Million in Transgender Student’s Suit
description: Gavin Grimm sued the Gloucester County, Va., school board after he was barred from using the boys’ bathroom. The dispute put him at the center of a debate over transgender rights.
content: A school board in Virginia has agreed to pay $1.3 million in legal fees to resolve a discrimination lawsuit filed by a former student whose efforts to use the boys’ bathroom put him at the center of a national debate over rights for transgender people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In Queens, the Mets Give Their Fans a Bronx Cheer
description: Showing off their sensitivity, Francisco Lindor, Javier Baez and Kevin Pillar celebrated a win by making thumbs-down gestures at the fans who had booed them.
content: The funniest thing about the Mets is the players’ pious self-image. Over and over, they emphasize that they’re all about positivity — and if you doubt them or point out a flaw, you’re a hater. They seem to believe they’re entitled to praise, no matter their performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: The S.E.C. head is considering banning a key way Robinhood makes money.
description: Gary Gensler, the chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called payment for order flow “an inherent conflict of interest.”
content: Gary Gensler, the chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said on Monday that a ban was “on the table” for a practice that underpins some of the most popular free stock-trading apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Mattel’s C.E.O. Wants Old Toys to Make New Money
description: The toy giant is doubling down on its film and TV ambitions.
content: Mattel went through three chief executives in four years before Ynon Kreiz took the job in 2018. He stood the test of time in part because of a big bet: taking Mattel's toys to Hollywood. The toy giant is partnering with Greta Gerwig and Margot Robbie to bring Barbie to life on the big screen, and creating films based on everything from UNO to Magic 8 Ball. It’s a strategy that draws on Kreiz’s past experience at entertainment companies like Maker Studios and Endemol, and one that draws inspiration from franchises like Transformers and companies like Lego, which Kreiz says was able to make “great movies out of bricks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner
title: Enchanted by the Mountains’ Ever-Changing Beauty: 45 Miles on the Teton Crest Trail
description: A three-day hike through the Teton Range in northwest Wyoming offers consistently stunning — and constantly unfolding — scenery.
content: When I arrived at my first campsite in Wyoming’s Teton Range, some 17 miles from the trailhead, I fully expected to collapse into my sleeping bag. My feet ached, my shoulders were cramping from the weight of my pack and, despite having spent much of the day hiking above 9,000 feet, I had yet to fully adjust to the altitude. I quickly set up my tent, pried my boots off and climbed inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Hurricane Ida Exposes Grid Weaknesses as New Orleans Goes Dark
description: A new natural gas power plant, meant to power the city in an emergency, did not come to the rescue when the storm disabled eight transmission lines.
content: Most of New Orleans went dark on Sunday after Hurricane Ida took out transmission lines and forced power plants offline. It was an all too familiar scene in a city that has often lost power during big storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Will Hearing Aids Ever Be Hip?
description: A new generation of more affordable and stylish hearing aids could help preserve mind, life and limb for millions.
content: You may be tired of reading columns about the dismally poor use of hearing aids by Americans. And, to be honest, I’d rather not have to write one every year or two. However, most people who could significantly benefit from these miracles of miniaturization still do not use them. But help is on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Tejada and Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombia’s Troubles Put a President’s Legacy on the Line
description: In an interview, Iván Duque defended his performance amid the pandemic and social strife, which could prompt a leftward shift in elections next year.
content: SEOUL — Iván Duque swept into Colombia’s presidency in 2018 as a young, little-known technocrat riding a surging right-wing movement. He tapped public anger against a peace deal that he said had treated the country’s deadly insurgents too softly. And he warned that the proposals of his left-wing opponent could stifle steady growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Yan Zhuang and Aurelien Breeden
title: How 2 Afghan Paralympians Defied the Odds to Get From Kabul to Tokyo
description: Their evacuation and eventual arrival in Japan involved multiple stops and many helping hands.
content: TOKYO — As his plane glided toward Tokyo, Andrew Parsons, president of the International Paralympic Committee, heard the bad news: two athletes from Afghanistan would not be able to fly safely from Kabul to Japan to compete in the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic Knocks on the Door of a Very Exclusive Club
description: Only five players have achieved a Grand Slam, the last being Steffi Graf in 1988. Winning four major titles in a calendar year — the holy grail of tennis — is improbably hard.
content: It has been more than half a century since a man completed tennis’s Grand Slam, and that man is ready for company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: She was lauded for challenging a Taliban member on live TV. Then she fled.
description: An Afghan news presenter was bold in a live interview with a Taliban member, but left Kabul when things began to look too dangerous.
content: In the fear-filled days after the Taliban stormed into Kabul, she was hailed as the brave young woman who questioned one of the militants on live television, providing hope that Afghan women might not lose all their freedoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins and Najim Rahim
title: Afghan Family Says Errant U.S. Missile Killed 10, Including 7 Children
description: Relatives, friends and colleagues of Zemari Ahmadi angrily dismissed any suggestion he had ties to ISIS-K. The U.S. military is investigating.
content: KABUL — Zemari Ahmadi was coming home Sunday evening, having dropped off colleagues from the local office of an American aid group where he worked, relatives and colleagues said in interviews Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: What the First Day of School May Look Like in Two Weeks
description: On Sept. 13, roughly one million public school students in New York City are set to return to their classrooms with no remote option available.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Kevin Granville
title: Oil and gasoline futures gyrate after Ida disrupts production.
description: Major oil and gas companies prepared for the hurricane by shutting down more than 90 percent of production and evacuated workers from platforms in the area.
content: Energy markets swirled on Monday as investors responded to the immediate disruption of Hurricane Ida while also trying to gauge the economic toll of rising hospitalizations in the United States caused by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: Louisiana is grappling with oxygen shortages in Ida’s aftermath.
description: Oxygen is in short supply across the Southeast, and rescuers anticipate more Covid-19-related distress calls.
content: Oxygen supplies are running critically low in hospitals across Louisiana — with some only having one or two days of supply left — and any interruption brought by Hurricane Ida’s destruction could be serious, according to Premier Inc., one of the largest hospital supply purchasing groups in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michiko Kakutani
title: When Charlie Watts Finally Made It to New York City
description: While his bandmates hit the Apollo, the reserved, jazz-loving drummer for the Stones could be found at Birdland.
content: In 1960, while working as an artist and graphic designer, and some years before the Rolling Stones were born, Charlie Watts began work on “Ode to a High-Flying Bird,” a captivating children’s book about his hero, the jazz great Charlie Parker. The book featured charming drawings of a bird named Charlie who realized he didn’t sound like most of the other birds, and who left home to fly to New York City, where he played “from his heart” and made a new nest for himself in “Birdland.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Jim Huylebroek, Matthieu Aikins and Dan Bilefsky
title: At Kabul airport, a sense of calm and resignation as deadline approaches.
description: In the final hours of the American military presence in Afghanistan, hope dwindled among the Afghans seeking to escape the country via the international airport in Kabul, the focal point of the U.S. evacuation effort since the Taliban takeover of the city just over two weeks ago.
content: In the final hours of the American military presence in Afghanistan, hope dwindled among the Afghans seeking to escape the country via the international airport in Kabul, the focal point of the U.S. evacuation effort since the Taliban takeover of the city just over two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Blush of Pineapple, From a New Online Source
description: Full Moon Fruits sells a wide variety of produce, including a sweet pink pineapple from Costa Rica.
content: Yes, they sell fragrant, juicy lychees, rambutans, mangosteens, dragon fruit, soursop and more. But the jewel in the crown from Full Moon Fruits, a fledgling fruit company, is the pink pineapple. With flesh the color of rosé, this rare pineapple from Costa Rica is irresistibly sweeter and less acidic than the yellow variety, delivering an almost cotton candy flavor. Uncut, they’re not so Instagrammable, sold without a crown of leaves because the tops are used to propagate subsequent crops. Matt Dembo, a marketing executive and a founder of the company, said he got into the fruit game as a sideline four years ago after sampling some of the fruits he found in stores in the Los Angeles area where he is based. He started sending various fruits, including some rare varieties, to friends, and before long was in business. He said he buys from small growers in California and in countries in Central America and elsewhere, preferably those who avoid chemicals. Prices start at about $5 for individual fruits by the pound; assortments are $39.99 and up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Are Censures of Politicians a Form of Free Speech or a Threat to It?
description: The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments this fall on whether the censure of an elected official in Houston ran afoul of the First Amendment.
content: WASHINGTON — Last summer, the City Council in River Falls, Wis., censured a member for calling an opponent of wearing masks during the coronavirus pandemic “a rancid tub of ignorant contagion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A New Breed of Crisis: War and Warming Collide in Afghanistan
description: Unrest and climate change are creating an agonizing feedback loop that punishes some of the world’s most vulnerable people.
content: Parts of Afghanistan have warmed twice as much as the global average. Spring rains have declined, most worryingly in some of the country’s most important farmland. Droughts are more frequent in vast swaths of the country, including a punishing dry spell now in the north and west, the second in three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: AstraZeneca requires its U.S. employees to be vaccinated.
description: All workers based in the United States who are returning to the office or visiting clients must be inoculated against the coronavirus, the pharmaceutical giant said.
content: AstraZeneca has mandated that its U.S.-based employees be vaccinated against the coronavirus if they are returning to the workplace or visiting customers, the company confirmed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Restarted Plutonium-Producing Reactor, U.N. Agency Warns
description: ​The activities at the sprawling nuclear complex in Yongbyon suggest that the country is once again ramping up its nuclear weapons program.
content: SEOUL — North Korea appears to have restarted a reactor​ in its main nuclear complex, the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog said in a report, an indication that the North has been ramping up its nuclear weapons program while talks with the United States remain stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: What Voters in a California Swing District Say About Afghanistan
description: In a battleground district, even some Trump voters said they were hesitant to hold President Biden accountable for the casualties and chaos in the U.S. pullout from Afghanistan.
content: HACIENDA HEIGHTS, Calif. — Brenda and Leo Ortiz had paid enough attention to the news from Afghanistan that it was hardly a surprise when their 11-year-old son asked them a question: How could so many Americans be killed last week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Chef’s Apron From Tom Colicchio
description: Tilit has partnered with the restaurateur for a sleek new apron, in three colors, with some proceeds going to Edible Schoolyard NYC.
content: The chef and restaurateur Tom Colicchio has collaborated on the design of an efficient new apron from Tilit, a company that makes chef’s garb. In blue or green, it’s made from organic duck cotton with waxed cotton; a white one is all duck. All have a leather strap and a front zip pocket. They are $115, with $10 of the price being donated to Edible Schoolyard NYC.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 30, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 30, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: Martin Short Kills in ‘Only Murders in the Building’
description: Short, Steve Martin and Selena Gomez star in a Hulu comedy about homicide, podcasts and the peculiarities of life in a New York luxury prewar building.
content: Martin Short gives a master class in “Only Murders in the Building,” the 10-episode Hulu series in which he stars with Selena Gomez and Steve Martin. (The first three episodes premiere Tuesday.) It’s not a class in acting or comedy so much as it is a seminar in agelessness and professionalism, and in Short’s unmatched ability to turn self-absorption into a virtue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Streusel Cake to Write Home About
description: The Vienna Cookie Company’s new streusel cakes are an ode to the coffee shop crumb cake, but with fillings that stand above.
content: The new streusel cakes from the Vienna Cookie Company in Baldwin, N.Y., are defined by their fillings of fruit, chocolate or nuts, sandwiched in between a tender cookielike base and a rich crumb topping. The cakes are the owner Heidi Riegler’s refinement of the typical New York coffee shop crumb cake and can go from breakfast to dessert. They will easily accept a pouf of yogurt, whipped cream or ice cream. Ms. Riegler uses local farmers’ market peaches and blueberries in her fillings, combines chocolate chips and ganache for the chocolate flavor, and soaks pecans in Grand Marnier for another variety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: In a final blow of the 20-year war, U.S. diplomats close their embassy and exit Kabul.
description: What was one of the largest U.S. diplomatic missions in the world will for now be based in Qatar, and focus largely on processing visas for refugees and other immigrants.
content: WASHINGTON — American diplomats have left Afghanistan, and the U.S. Embassy in Kabul will remain closed, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday, after the military announced that it had completed its withdrawal from the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Thomas Fuller
title: Evacuations Ordered Near Lake Tahoe as the Caldor Fire Chokes Region
description: The fire had spread to more than 186,000 acres and was 15 percent contained, according to Cal Fire.
content: A wildfire that had burned through remote areas in the Sierra Nevada for two weeks crested a ridge on Monday and began descending toward the major population centers along Lake Tahoe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A 1932 house in Berkeley, a midcentury-modern home in the Hollywood Hills and a two-cabin compound in Boonville.
content: This house has been in the same family for more than 50 years and has been well maintained, preserving original details like stained-glass windows and colorful 1930s tile in the kitchen and bathrooms. It is in the Thousand Oaks section of Berkeley, about 10 minutes by car from downtown and the University of California campus. The neighborhood’s main thoroughfare, Solano Avenue, about a mile away, is lined with markets and casual restaurants. Closer to the house (about a five-minute drive or a 10-minute walk) is the Kensington Farmers’ Market, where vendors sell locally produced goods on Sundays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Afghanistan, Ida, Mask Mandates: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: When Frederick Douglass Met Andrew Johnson
description: In “The Failed Promise,” a new book about Reconstruction and Johnson’s impeachment, Robert S. Levine looks closely at the perspective of Douglass and other Black leaders.
content: Andrew Johnson, having assumed the highest office after Lincoln’s assassination in 1865, wasn’t only an accidental president but also a racist one — about that, Robert S. Levine says, there cannot be any doubt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Keith Bradsher
title: The World Is Still Short of Everything. Get Used to It.
description: Pandemic-related product shortages — from computer chips to construction materials — were supposed to be resolved by now. Instead, the world has gained a lesson in the ripple effects of disruption.
content: Like most people in the developed world, Kirsten Gjesdal had long taken for granted her ability to order whatever she needed and then watch the goods arrive, without any thought about the factories, container ships and trucks involved in delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How a Question on Sign Language Led to a Deeper Look at Deaf Culture
description: To understand the process of name signing, a Times team turned to people who knew it best.
content: How does a person get a name sign — the series of unique gestures used to identify someone in American Sign Language? For a team of Times journalists, the process of answering that question underscored the importance of two storytelling basics — rely on experts and think of the audience — and resulted in an interactive article in July that provided a broader understanding of deaf culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: A Quarter-Century Ago, She Landed a Brooklyn Unicorn
description: Her comfortable apartment on a tree-lined street was a special find, but the real gem turned out to be her community-focused landlord.
content: For 25 years, Kiera Coffee has lived in an apartment that she originally couldn’t afford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candice Frederick
title: Nia DaCosta on ‘Candyman’ and the Power of Terrifying Legends
description: For her horror redo, the filmmaker confronted the pressures for success. “There are a lot of people that you want to do well for, and that can be daunting.”
content: This article contains spoilers for the new film “Candyman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: How Does Biden Recover From His Week From Hell?
description: It won’t be easy, but it won’t be impossible, either.
content: Bret Stephens: Hello, Gail. I hope these last two weeks of vacation have been nicer for you than they’ve been for Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Where Companies Stand on Vaccine Requirements and Return to Office
description: The Delta variant has upended office return plans. Here’s when large companies expert to have employees back at their desks.
content: The Delta variant of the coronavirus has disrupted back-to-office plans for some companies, while others are still expecting employees to be at their desks in September or sooner. Here’s the latest on when companies have announced that they plan to return to the office, and whether they’ll require vaccines when they do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Rick Rojas and Patricia Mazzei
title: Hurricane Veterans Were Stunned by Ida: ‘It’s Never Been as Bad’
description: Some small towns outside New Orleans were inundated. Trapped residents waited for daylight, when rescue boats could make their way through the floodwaters.
content: JEFFERSON PARISH, La. — Jordan Roque pulled his Chevy pickup truck onto the last stretch of highway outside of town that was not inundated by water on Monday, hauling an airboat. Hurricane Ida had turned the road into a makeshift boat launch, and Mr. Roque was on a mission to find his relatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Aaliyah’s ‘One in a Million’ Finally Cracks the Billboard Top 10
description: Music from the R&B singer, who died in 2001, started to arrive on streaming services, helping her 1996 album, “One in a Million,” reach No. 10 for the first time.
content: Vinyl helped Olivia Rodrigo reclaim the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart this week, while a long-delayed arrival on streaming brought a 25-year-old album by Aaliyah to the Top 10 for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Oysters, in the Form of a C.S.A.
description: The World’s Your Oyster Company delivers cultivated oysters from Maine and Eastern Canada to New York City and the Hudson Valley.
content: Faced with the pandemic putting an end to his New York bartending job, Aaron Waldman returned to Maine, his home state, and a year or so ago started the World’s Your Oyster Company, distributing cultivated oysters from Maine and Eastern Canada to restaurants. Earlier this year he expanded his market, offering oysters to consumers on a C.S.A. basis, with monthly or bimonthly deliveries to locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Hudson Valley. Other shellfish like clams can be included. Memberships in the September-October C.S.A. are now open and feature oyster farms owned or managed by women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Steady, Stoic Cantlay Outlasts a Mighty DeChambeau in Maryland
description: The BMW Championship was settled after six gripping playoff holes between two rising stars of the post-Tiger Woods generation.
content: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Patrick Cantlay, a creative if stoic player, was asked on Saturday night to look forward to Sunday’s final round of the BMW Championship when he would be paired with Bryson DeChambeau, the tinkering and volatile former college physics major.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremi Suri
title: History Is Clear. America’s Military Is Way Too Big.
description: Global military dominance has not lived up to its hype for American interests.
content: For much of its history, the United States was a big country with a small peacetime military. World War II changed that permanently: American leaders decided that a country with new global obligations needed a very large peacetime military, including a nuclear arsenal and a worldwide network of bases. They hoped overwhelming military capacity would avert another world war, deter adversaries and encourage foreign countries to follow our wishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: What to Know About the Investigation Into Tyler Skaggs’s Death
description: Eric Kay, a former Angels employee, stands accused of supplying the pitcher with the drugs that killed him. His trial will begin in October.
content: A dark cloud has hung over the Los Angeles Angels and Major League Baseball since pitcher Tyler Skaggs was found dead inside a team hotel in Texas on July 1, 2019. Skaggs was 27 at the time, had just gotten married the year before and some believed he was poised to take the next step in his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Point Is That People in the South Are Suffering
description: We need to learn to talk about climate change in a way that isn’t so politically charged.
content: NASHVILLE — By now you’ve probably seen photos of the apocalyptic flooding in Middle Tennessee’s Dickson, Hickman, Houston and Humphreys Counties on Aug. 21, though it’s understandable if you scrolled right on past without really looking. There’s a déjà vu quality to such images. Cars lifted by some unstoppable force and returned to earth cattywampus. Houses at odds with their foundations, or just gone. Holes where roads used to be. The debris field of a bombing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Erin Woo
title: Schemer or Naïf? Elizabeth Holmes Is Going to Trial.
description: The trial for the founder of Theranos, the once high-flying blood testing start-up, will cap a saga of Silicon Valley hubris, ambition and deception.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — After four years, repeated delays and the birth of her baby, Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the blood testing start-up Theranos, is set to stand trial for fraud, capping a saga of Silicon Valley hubris, ambition and deception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Can Afghanistan’s leading broadcaster survive the Taliban?
description: Over the past two decades, the Afghan broadcaster Tolo has been known for provocative programs like “Burka Avenger,” in which an animated superheroine uses martial arts to vanquish villains trying to shut down a girls’ school.
content: Over the past two decades, the Afghan broadcaster Tolo has been known for provocative programs like “Burka Avenger,” in which an animated superheroine uses martial arts to vanquish villains trying to shut down a girls’ school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: On Death Row in Texas, a Last Request: A Prayer and ‘Human Contact’
description: Scheduled for execution on Sept. 8, John Henry Ramirez is suing to have his Baptist pastor lay hands on him as he dies.
content: LIVINGSTON, Texas — John Henry Ramirez and Dana Moore both quote the same passage of the Bible when they explain their friendship. “I was sick and you looked after me,” Jesus says in the book of Matthew, describing God ushering righteous people into eternal life. “I was in prison and you came to visit me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Is Vaccine Immunity Waning?
description: It may not really be waning much — which means universal booster shots may do little good.
content: Late last month, researchers in Israel released some alarming new Covid-19 data. The data showed that many Israelis who had been among the first to receive the vaccine were nonetheless catching the Covid virus. Israelis who had been vaccinated later were not getting infected as often.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Demand Surges for Deworming Drug for Covid, Despite Scant Evidence It Works
description: Prescriptions for ivermectin have jumped to more than 88,000 per week, some pharmacists are reporting shortages and people are overdosing on forms of the drug meant for horses.
content: For the past week, Dr. Gregory Yu, an emergency physician in San Antonio, has received the same daily requests from his patients, some vaccinated for Covid-19 and others unvaccinated: They ask him for ivermectin, a drug typically used to treat parasitic worms that has repeatedly failed in clinical trials to help people infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch One of the Best Current Comedies on TV
description: “What We Do in the Shadows” is back. Our TV critic also recommends a beachy Australian procedural.
content: This is a preview of the Watching newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox four times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From Louisiana in Ida’s Wake
description: A day after the Category 4 storm struck the state, rescue operations were underway amid widespread power outages, flooding and wind damage.
content: After the sun rose, and the wind and rain ceased, residents across southeastern Louisiana began to survey the wreckage from Hurricane Ida, which hit the state on Sunday. The Category 4 storm had maximum sustained winds of 150 miles per hour when it made landfall, causing widespread power outages and flooding. It had caused at least three deaths as of Monday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: For Benoît Paire, Just Playing in the U.S. Open Felt Like Winning
description: Last year the French player missed the tournament after a positive Covid-19 test kept him confined to his hotel room. Even after a first-round loss, Paire felt free.
content: A year ago, French tennis player Benoît Paire spent the U.S. Open isolated in his Long Island hotel room after testing positive for Covid-19, unable to take his place in the draw and unable to find his happy place in the aftermath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Lights Flickered in New York City. Why Did the Subways Grind to a Halt?
description: Elected officials wanted to know why a brief power disruption was followed by widespread problems in the subway system.
content: For most New Yorkers, it was a blink-or-you-miss-it event. Lights flickered across the city on Sunday night. Some clocks reset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Is This the Coldest Summer of the Rest of Our Lives?
description: 2021 has been hot enough.
content: There’s a dark joke about this year’s extreme temperatures that has been haunting me for weeks: This is the coldest summer of the rest of our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Band of Robbers Tie Hostages to Cars in Brazilian City
description: The assault was the latest launched by well-trained and heavily-armed bands on robbers targeting small cities at night.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Heavily-armed assailants stormed a small city in southeast Brazil early Monday, in a brazen operation to rob banks that included explosives, charred vehicles and hostages that were tied to the roof of cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: In Afghanistan, an Unceremonious End, and a Shrouded Beginning
description: The last American flight from Afghanistan left behind a host of unfulfilled promises and anxious questions about the country’s fate.
content: The end of the United States’ longest war was unceremonious — trash blowing across the single airstrip of Kabul’s international airport, Afghans lingering outside the gates, still hoping in vain for evacuation, Taliban firing victoriously into the night sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Jake Paul’s Big Night: 16,000 Fans, a Tweet From LeBron and a Win
description: Paul, the social media star turned boxer, hoped his eight-round, split-decision victory over Tyron Woodley would give him legitimacy in the sport.
content: In the fifth round of their boxing match on Sunday, after Jake Paul nearly landed a clean blow to Tyron Woodley’s face, Paul sneered at his opponent and then playfully pretended to lick his gloves. The orange mitts were coordinated with his orange trunks, which were equipped with an electronic screen that projected his name near his waist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: In R. Kelly Trial, the Verdict May Hinge on a Circle of Enablers
description: Accusations of sexual misconduct have long followed the R&B star. But central to the charges against Mr. Kelly are the people who prosecutors say made a pattern of abuse possible.
content: There were the assistants, who said they were warned to remain silent as they chauffeured female guests to their superstar employer’s Chicago-area mansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: New York’s Brief Hot Restaurant Summer: Bread Binges and Tabletop Coke
description: Restaurants steeled themselves for a post-pandemic summer of debauchery. In June and July, they got it, but it ended quickly.
content: As the Covid-19 vaccines rolled out in the spring, many New Yorkers anticipated a summer filled with rampant pleasure and maskless debauchery. The overwhelming energy was: We’re off the hook, and it’s time to party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Here are some ways to help victims of the storm.
description: Charitable agencies help communities in need after natural disasters. But there are also fraudsters preying on the emotion and helplessness that follows the destruction.
content: Hurricane Ida’s devastating winds, flooding and heavy rains swept through southeastern Louisiana on Sunday, and the brunt of its destructive path became apparent on Monday: Homes and businesses were damaged or destroyed, and hundreds of thousands of people were left without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What’s Better, a Prize or a Patent?
description: Elon Musk has put up $100 million in prize money for a way to extract carbon from the atmosphere.
content: Earlier this year, Elon Musk, the billionaire co-founder and chief executive of Tesla, promised $100 million in prizes to inventors who come up with ways to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. The rewards, which will be awarded by the X Prize Foundation, are part of a cornucopia of cash that’s being dangled to induce innovation around the world. The European Innovation Council, the MacArthur Foundation, and the U.S. government through the America Competes Reauthorization Act of 2010 are among those splashing around big bucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: Rachael Leigh Cook Was Always Worth the Bet
description: After more than 25 years in Hollywood, the star of millennial classics like “She’s All That” and “Josie and the Pussycats” is ready for a new chapter.
content: Rachael Leigh Cook is having a full-circle moment. Twenty-two years after she descended a staircase in a little red dress to the beat of Sixpence None the Richer, the “She’s All That” actress finds herself once again in a teen makeover movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Can Afghanistan’s Leading Broadcaster Survive the Taliban?
description: Tolo came to prominence with hard-hitting news, raucous reality shows and lurid Turkish soap operas. Now there are ominous signs that a violent media clampdown is underway.
content: Over the past two decades, the Afghan broadcaster Tolo has been known for provocative programs like “Burka Avenger,” in which an animated superheroine uses martial arts to vanquish villains trying to shut down a girls’ school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘What We Do in the Shadows’ and ‘Yannick’
description: “What We Do in the Shadows” returns for a third season on FX. And PBS airs a documentary about the orchestra conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 30-Sept. 5. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: Naomi Osaka and Andy Murray are among the players to watch on Monday.
description: Looking for some good matches on Monday, the first day of the U.S. Open? Naomi Osaka will open the defense of her women’s title to lead off the night session, and Andy Murray, the 2012 U.S. Open champion, will play third-seeded Stefanos Tsitsipas in an afternoon match.
content: Looking for some good matches on Monday, the first day of the U.S. Open? Naomi Osaka will open the defense of her women’s title to lead off the night session, and Andy Murray, the 2012 U.S. Open champion, will play third-seeded Stefanos Tsitsipas in an afternoon match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: A SPAC Counterattack
description: A group of law firms lined up to condemn lawsuits filed against the contentious blank-check investment vehicles.
content: When 49 major national law firms banded together late last week to condemn lawsuits targeting special purpose acquisition companies, the deal-making world took notice. To get “firms who regularly litigate against each other to agree on something” is impressive, Joseph Grundfest, a Stanford Law professor and former S.E.C. commissioner, told DealBook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: When the ‘Silent Majority’ Isn’t White
description: The new media obsession with moderate minorities.
content: In her 1990 book “Fear of Falling,” Barbara Ehrenreich detailed how the widely broadcast violence at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago led to an immediate, dramatic paradigm shift in media coverage. In the month before the event, Mayor Richard Daley had denounced the various anti-Vietnam War protest groups who were planning to converge outside the city’s International Amphitheater. When those protesters arrived, Daley fought back with his police force who, on Aug. 28, attacked protesters in Grant Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: A W.H.O. official urges measures to keep schools open.
description: GENEVA — The coronavirus has caused “the most catastrophic disruption of education in history,” and it is vital for children’s learning and mental health that schools take the necessary measures to open and to continue classroom-based lessons, the World Health Organization’s top European official said on Monday.
content: GENEVA — The coronavirus has caused “the most catastrophic disruption of education in history,” and it is vital for children’s learning and mental health that schools take the necessary measures to open and to continue classroom-based lessons, the World Health Organization’s top European official said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Catie Edmondson
title: ‘We Have to Try’: Lawmakers Rush to Assist in Afghanistan Evacuations.
description: Frustrated with the Biden administration’s plans and inundated with requests for help, members of Congress in both parties have thrown themselves into extraction efforts.
content: WASHINGTON — Consumed with trying to help dozens of Afghans escape their country as U.S. troops prepared to withdraw, aides to Representative Michael Waltz, Republican of Florida, shifted their work schedules, coming in after midnight so they could talk evacuees through Taliban checkpoints.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: What Do You Want to Know About Covid?
description: We’re in a confusing stage of the pandemic. Have questions about the Delta variant, booster shots or anything else? We’ll ask the experts.
content: How worried should vaccinated people be about the Delta variant? How much risk do children face? Which parts of the Covid story are being overhyped, and which deserve more attention?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
title: Hundreds of thousands of people are without power.
description: Some customers who were in the direct path of the storm may not get electric service back for weeks. Phone networks also were disrupted in the region.
content: It will take days just for utility crews to determine the extent of the storm damage to the New Orleans power grid, and far longer to restore power to the region, officials of Entergy Louisiana said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: In Baton Rouge, a hospital strained by the pandemic braces for storm victims.
description: BATON ROUGE, La. — After a powerful storm blows through Baton Rouge, the emergency room at Our Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center generally fills with patients suffering from burns and injuries from falls and power tool accidents.
content: BATON ROUGE, La. — After a powerful storm blows through Baton Rouge, the emergency room at Our Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center generally fills with patients suffering from burns and injuries from falls and power tool accidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Exile or Jail: The Grim Choice Facing Russian Opposition Leaders
description: Experts say the current exodus of journalists and dissidents is the biggest wave of political emigration in the country’s post-Soviet history.
content: MOSCOW — Evoking the dark era of Soviet repression, Russian politicians and journalists are being driven into exile in growing numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson, Ashley Southall and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: At Birth, She Already Had a Case File. At 7 Years Old, She Was Dead.
description: A child welfare system meant to protect Julissia Batties from an abusive home life failed the ultimate test.
content: Even amid the constant churn of men and women in and out of the busy Bronx bodega, one customer stood out as she walked to the deli counter to place her order: a cheeseburger and a bagel with cream cheese and jelly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Unvaccinated U.S. visitors could soon face new restrictions on travel to Europe.
description: The European Union’s leaders removed the United States from a “safe list.” Individual countries in the bloc are not obliged to follow suit, however.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union on Monday recommended that its member countries place new travel restrictions on unvaccinated visitors from the United States, a fresh blow to the continent’s ailing tourism sector and a sign that potential measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus might remain in place for months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: War and Climate Change Collide in Afghanistan
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Aug. 30, 2021.
content: “The war has exacerbated climate change impacts. For 10 years, over 50 percent of the national budget goes to the war. Now there is no government, and the future is unclear. Our current situation today is completely hopeless.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: This Rosh Hashana Salad Is a Fresh Take on Ancient Flavors
description: For the Jewish New Year, Joan Nathan composes a dish that pays tribute to foods that the biblical Canaanites might have eaten.
content: When planning meals for the fall Jewish holidays, I often think back to the food from Canaan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: R. Kelly’s First Male Accuser Says the Singer Promised Fame for Sex
description: On the eighth day of Mr. Kelly’s trial, a man and woman both testified that they were underage when they met the singer; the woman, now 44, described being raped.
content: The racketeering trial of the R&B star R. Kelly resumed in Brooklyn on Monday with the testimony of two new accusers, including the first male accuser to take the stand against the singer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Florida withholds money from school districts over mask mandates.
description: The state made good on a threat to school districts that required masks, in defiance of an order by the governor.
content: The Florida Department of Education has withheld funds from two school districts that made masks mandatory in classrooms this fall, state officials announced on Monday, making good on a threat that local school boards that required students to wear masks would be punished financially.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Kathy Hochul Wants to Make One Thing Clear: She Is Not Cuomo
description: In her first acts as New York’s new governor, Ms. Hochul has sought to distance herself from her predecessor, Andrew Cuomo, who resigned under pressure.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — In her first days as governor of New York, Kathy C. Hochul has gone to great lengths to demonstrate that whatever kind of leadership style she might adopt, it will be far from that of her disgraced predecessor, Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The final hours in Afghanistan.
content: The last U.S. troops have left the airport in Kabul, signifying the end of a two-decade fight and the beginning of a Taliban-controlled chapter for the country, U.S. military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Flagg
title: The Black Mortality Gap, and a Document Written in 1910
description: Some clues on why health care fails Black Americans can be found in the Flexner Report.
content: Black Americans die at higher rates than white Americans at nearly every age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: New data confirm Covid vaccines provide strong protection against hospitalization.
description: A panel of experts advising the C.D.C. also discussed data showing that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines bring a small risk of heart problems.
content: New data presented to a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention committee provided more evidence that the Covid-19 vaccines provided robust protection against severe disease through July, after the Delta variant of the coronavirus had spread widely through the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Beta
title: Leslie Winer’s Music Was a Mystery in 1990. She Still Likes It That Way.
description: Fans of her early trip-hop-like songs included John Peel and Boy George. A new compilation puts her innovations in a fresh context.
content: Leslie Winer seemed poised for stardom in 1990. The face of Valentino and Christian Dior the decade before — “the first androgynous model,” as Jean Paul Gaultier called her — had turned to music. Her first single, “Skin,” featured a club-ready backbeat and a hook about love and acceptance perfect for the United Colors of Benetton era. John Maybury, the director of Sinead O’Connor’s “Nothing Compares 2 U” video, made the track’s clip. But Winer’s chiseled visage didn’t appear in the abstract video, and “Skin” simply disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Lee (Scratch) Perry, Bob Marley Mentor and Reggae Innovator, Dies at 85
description: With a four-track tape recorder in his Jamaican home studio, he opened surreal sonic vistas and cultivated the image of a mad genius.
content: Lee (Scratch) Perry, the innovative Jamaican producer who mentored Bob Marley and pushed reggae into the sonic avant-garde with his dub productions, died on Sunday in Lucca, Jamaica. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: New South Wales, Australia’s most populous state, has a record rise in daily cases.
description: The Australian state of New South Wales on Monday reported its highest daily number of coronavirus cases since the pandemic began, as infections driven by the Delta variant continued to surge and millions remained in lockdown.
content: The Australian state of New South Wales on Monday reported its highest daily number of coronavirus cases since the pandemic began, as infections driven by the Delta variant continued to surge and millions remained in lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: In Literary Organizations, Diversity Disputes Keep Coming
description: Conflicts over race, culture and inclusion have roiled the Romance Writers of America, the Society of Children’s Book Writers and Illustrators and other groups devoted to books and literature.
content: A rescinded award. Board members resigning in anger. And many public apologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Charlie Savage
title: White House Weighs Clemency to Keep Some Drug Offenders Confined at Home
description: Biden officials are exploring what should be done with inmates in home confinement whenever the pandemic emergency ends.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is considering using his clemency powers to commute the sentences of certain federal drug offenders released to home confinement during the pandemic rather than forcing them to return to prison after the pandemic emergency ends, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden receives the bodies of soldiers killed in the Kabul bombing.
description: A gray C-17 transport plane landed in Delaware shortly after 8 a.m. on Sunday. It carried the remains of 11 Marines, a Navy medic and an Army staff sergeant, who collectively could be the last Americans to die in the war in Afghanistan.
content: A gray C-17 transport plane landed in Delaware shortly after 8 a.m. on Sunday. It carried the remains of 11 Marines, a Navy medic and an Army staff sergeant, who collectively could be the last Americans to die in the war in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: The Dogs of 9/11: Their Failed Searches for Life Helped Sustain It
description: Two exhibitions in New York recognize the search and rescue dogs who combed through the World Trade Center wreckage, trying to find survivors.
content: For more than two weeks after the twin towers collapsed on 9/11, hundreds of search and rescue dogs hunted for signs of life in the smoldering ruins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Nick Saban, 7 Titles in, on Offenses, Defenses and Changes in College Sports
description: Saban, the 69-year-old Alabama football coach, has a new deal and another national championship. Now the Crimson Tide taskmaster is starting his 15th season in Tuscaloosa.
content: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Around the time Bear Bryant was building the University of Alabama into a dominant force in college football, Nick Saban was a boy washing cars in West Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Asked to Block Texas Law Banning Most Abortions
description: The law, set to go into effect on Wednesday, bans abortions after about six weeks and deputizes citizens to file suits to enforce it.
content: WASHINGTON — Abortion providers in Texas asked the Supreme Court on Monday to block a state law banning abortions in the state as early as six weeks into pregnancy. The law, one of the most restrictive in the nation, is poised to go into effect on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Monday
description: Andy Murray and Stefanos Tsitsipas meet for the first time, and the spotlight shines once again on defending champion Naomi Osaka.
content: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN; 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jacques Rogge, Who Led Olympic Committee, Dies at 79
description: Taking over in the wake of an ethics scandal, Dr. Rogge was credited with restoring stability and taking a hard line against doping.
content: Jacques Rogge, who became president of the International Olympic Committee in 2001, when the organization was still reeling from an ethics scandal, and helped restore stability during his 12 years in charge while taking a strong stand against doping, has died. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Temnycky
title: It’s Now or Never. Biden Must Stop Putin’s Beloved Pipeline.
description: Nord Stream 2 would be catastrophic for all of Europe.
content: For the first time in over four years, a Ukrainian president is coming to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Putting the ‘Open’ Back Into the U.S. Open
description: The Grand Slam tournament that signals the end of summer in New York welcomes fans who have been vaccinated against Covid-19 to pack the house when the main draw begins Monday.
content: It has been two years since tennis fans queued for $25 lobster rolls at the United States Open, 24 long months since tipsy spectators could shout from the upper deck of Arthur Ashe Stadium during rowdy night sessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Howie Rose Steps Away From Mets, but Plans to Return Next Year
description: The longtime play-by-play broadcaster is undergoing treatment for an undisclosed medical condition. “The doctors tell me the prognosis is good.”
content: Howie Rose, the longtime Mets radio and television play-by-play broadcaster, announced on Monday that he will miss the final month of the regular season to have surgery for an undisclosed medical issue. Rose said he will have the operation on Friday and will announce his last game of the season either Tuesday or Wednesday, depending on the weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Why So Many Tennis Players Don’t Want the Covid Vaccine
description: Despite the possible consequences of not being vaccinated — illness and the loss of income and opportunity to play — tennis players have been stubbornly slow to get the vaccine.
content: When the United States Tennis Association announced on Friday that proof of coronavirus vaccination would be required for all spectators 12 and older to enter the grounds of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, it widened a gulf between the spectators and the players they’ll be watching at the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: How Alcohol Affects the Heart
description: A new study has found that even moderate drinking can increase the risk of A-fib, a heart rhythm abnormality that afflicts some 3 million Americans.
content: A new study has found that consuming alcohol, even as little as one can of beer or one glass of wine, can quickly increase the risk of a common type of cardiac arrhythmia known as atrial fibrillation in people who have a history of the condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Sydney Harper, Eric Krupke, Austin Mitchell, Daniel Guillemette, Diana Nguyen, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: The Tale of California’s Recall Election
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom could face removal from office in the coming days. How did the popular Democrat get to this point?
content: Recall efforts in California are a political peculiarity — it’s easier to recall a governor there than in almost any other state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Wide Awake at 3. a.m.? Our Readers Offer Advice.
description: Well readers share a range of strategies they use to get back to sleep in the middle of the night.
content: Most sleep experts offer standard advice to people who occasionally wake up at 3 a.m. and can’t fall back to sleep after 20 minutes or so: Ignore the clock, get out of bed and do a calming activity. Then, return to bed when you start to feel sleepy again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lorde Steals Her Sunshine Back
description: How successful is a sunny new phase of her career, and what does it mean to choose to move away from the expectations of superstardom?
content: Lorde’s new album “Solar Power” marks a pivot for the New Zealand singer-songwriter, away from the insular and intimate relationship tension captured on her last album, “Melodrama” from 2017, into a brighter palette and songs about embracing wellness and posi vibes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph G. Allen and Helen Jenkins
title: The Hard Covid-19 Questions We’re Not Asking
description: It’s time for the U.S. to define what the goals are for Covid-19.
content: While the availability of vaccines refocused the U.S. response to the pandemic, many policy questions remain. Should vaccinated people get boosters? Does everyone need to wear a mask? Are unvaccinated children safe in schools?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: In an effort to lure Berliners, Covid shots are made available on a train.
description: BERLIN — In an effort to convince holdouts to get inoculated against the coronavirus, a train of the S-Bahn, the iconic red-and-orange line in Berlin, was converted into a mobile vaccination center on Monday.
content: BERLIN — In an effort to convince holdouts to get inoculated against the coronavirus, a train of the S-Bahn, the iconic red-and-orange line in Berlin, was converted into a mobile vaccination center on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Hurricane Ida makes landfall in a Covid hotspot.
content: Hurricane Ida made landfall southwest of New Orleans on Sunday as a Category 4 hurricane before moving into Mississippi, walloping hospitals in two states that were already brimming with Covid patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A U.S. drone strike in Kabul.
content: A U.S. drone strike in Kabul yesterday blew up a vehicle laden with explosives that officials said was an “imminent ISIS-K threat” to the airport, three days after a bombing killed about 170 civilians and 13 American service members. Afghans said that the drone strike killed a number of civilians, including children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Human Most of All: In Moscow, a Theater Stages ‘Gorbachev’
description: The Latvian director Alvis Hermanis’s bioplay is an ode to the love story of Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev, and portrays the former leader in all his humanity.
content: MOSCOW — In August 1991, Mikhail Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, returned to Moscow with his family from house arrest in Crimea after a K.G.B.-managed anti-democracy coup had failed to depose him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: The U.S. Is Off the E.U.’s ‘Safe List.’ What Does That Mean for Americans Traveling to Europe?
description: The bloc dropped the United States from the list of countries considered safe and recommended restricting travel for unvaccinated American travelers. But changes, if any, won’t be immediate. Here’s what you need to know.
content: On Monday, the European Union removed the United States from its “safe list” of countries whose residents can travel to its 27 member states without requirements such as quarantine and testing. This generated confusion, with some people writing on social media that Americans have been banned from visiting Europe. That’s not actually what the recommendation means. Americans have not been explicitly prohibited from going anywhere in Europe. But vaccination status may soon affect travel, even more than it did before. Here’s a look at what the new developments mean for vaccinated and unvaccinated people:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Like (Fashion Designer) Mother, Like (Managing Partner) Daughter
description: Before the anti-poufy gowns she designed in the ’90s or the sustainable satin she uses now, there was just Ines Di Santo, her daughter and a discarded sewing machine.
content: In 1974, Ines Di Santo, who was 22 at the time, left her home in Argentina and arrived alone in Toronto, pregnant, nearly penniless and with just one suitcase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Snake Oil Theory of the Modern Right
description: How the nutritional supplement business has helped foster extremism.
content: You don’t hear much these days about “economic anxiety.” Most observers acknowledge that the rise of the Trumpist right was driven by racial and social antagonism, not economic populism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Kate Forms in the Atlantic
description: Forecasters said that Kate, the 11th named storm of a busy hurricane season, was not likely to strengthen significantly as it moves over the open waters of the central Atlantic Ocean.
content: As residents along the Louisiana coast surveyed the damage left after Hurricane Ida came ashore, and a day after Tropical Storm Julian formed and was quickly downgraded, Tropical Storm Kate formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday, becoming the 11th named storm of a busy hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: N.J. will end pandemic unemployment benefits this weekend.
description: Gov. Phil Murphy has decided to let the Covid-related benefits expire on Saturday, rather than use federal relief funds to extend them as the White House has suggested.
content: New Jersey will end special unemployment benefits put in place during the pandemic when they expire on Saturday, rather than using federal relief funds to extend them, the state’s governor announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Sip of Paradise
description: St. Agrestis’s new aperitivo, Paradiso, designed for the spritz, has a bracing citrus profile and a spicy aroma.
content: St. Agrestis, the Brooklyn distiller known for its Italian approach to amaro and cocktails like the Negroni, has introduced a new aperitivo. Called Paradiso and sold in a distinctive tapered bottle like St. Agrestis’s other products, it’s the mellow yang to the decidedly bitter yin of the company’s Inferno Bitter and is formulated to be the foundation of a spritz. The honey-colored 40-proof spirit is made with a wine base, gets its bracing profile from blood orange and citrus peels, and has a spicy aroma with a hint of baked apple on the palate. Come fall, blend it in a spritz with sparkling hard cider (try Brooklyn Cider House Bone Dry) or simply enjoy it on the rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Ida Hit One of the Country’s Biggest Oil and Chemical Hubs
description: Louisiana’s 17 oil refineries account for nearly a fifth of the nation’s capacity. Past hurricanes have caused toxic spills.
content: The most intense hurricane on record to strike Louisiana swept through one of the nation’s largest chemical, petroleum and natural gas hubs. And while it may take days or weeks for the full extent of the storm’s impact to become clear, early reports of damage have heightened concerns over the vulnerability of the region’s fossil fuel infrastructure to intensifying storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Last Call for Tomatoes and Corn
description: The end of summer is in sight, so make all the hot-weather recipes on your to-do list.
content: Good morning. It’s been a harrowing end to the month. Most of New Orleans woke up without power after Hurricane Ida pummeled the coast of Louisiana, and it seems especially cruel after a summer already rife with climate-related disasters. Wherever you are, stay safe and take care of yourself and your loved ones. We’ll be here when you’re ready to cook again.
source.name: The New York Times
